Key Arguments: The legislation risks suppressing valuable information necessary for informed public decision-making.
It contradicts the principles of freedom of information and freedom of speech.
If not managed correctly, it could adversely affect human rights.
The legislation could lead to severe restrictions by platform providers, limiting access to public interest information.
The Bill only targets digital platforms and ignores misinformation from mainstream media.
There is support for ACMA monitoring all platforms and media outlets to prevent harmful information.
A code of practice for all platform and media service providers is supported.
The terms misinformation and disinformation are subjective and need clearer definitions.
Main Themes: Potential overreach and adverse effects on human rights
Need for comprehensive coverage including mainstream media
Support for monitoring and a code of practice
Subjectivity and definition of misinformation and disinformation
Notable Quotes: It has the risk, if not managed correctly, of suppressing valuable information that would otherwise not be available to the general public.
It goes against the principles of freedom of information and freedom of speech.
The term misinformation and disinformation is quite subjective and needs more careful consideration and a clearer definition.
